trans-unit.source: Enable offline sync for your Azure Mobile App (Windows 8.1) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Enable offline sync for your Azure Mobile App (Windows 8.1) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use an Azure Mobile App to cache and sync offline data in your Windows Store application
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use an Azure Mobile App to cache and sync offline data in your Windows Store application

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to add offline support to a Windows 8.1 Store or Phone app using an Azure Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to add offline support to a Windows 8.1 Store or Phone app using an Azure Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: Offline sync allows end-users to interact with a mobile app--viewing, adding, or modifying data--even when there is no network connection.
trans-unit.target: Offline sync allows end-users to interact with a mobile app--viewing, adding, or modifying data--even when there is no network connection.

trans-unit.source: Changes are stored in a local database; once the device is back online, these changes are synced with the remote backend.
trans-unit.target: Changes are stored in a local database; once the device is back online, these changes are synced with the remote backend.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will update the Windows 8.1 app project from the tutorial [Create a Windows app] to support the offline features of Azure Mobile Apps.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will update the Windows 8.1 app project from the tutorial [Create a Windows app] to support the offline features of Azure Mobile Apps.

trans-unit.source: If you do not use the downloaded quick start server project, you must add the data access extension packages to your project.
trans-unit.target: If you do not use the downloaded quick start server project, you must add the data access extension packages to your project.

trans-unit.source: For more information about server extension packages, see <linkText>Work with the .NET backend server SDK for Azure Mobile Apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about server extension packages, see <linkText>Work with the .NET backend server SDK for Azure Mobile Apps</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the offline sync feature, see the topic [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps].
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the offline sync feature, see the topic [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps].

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires the following:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires the following:

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 running on Windows 8.1.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 running on Windows 8.1.

trans-unit.source: Completion of <linkText>Create a Windows app[create a windows app]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Completion of <linkText>Create a Windows app[create a windows app]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Mobile Services SQLite Store version 2.0.0-beta[sqlite store nuget]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Mobile Services SQLite Store version 2.0.0-beta[sqlite store nuget]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQLite for Windows 8.1</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQLite for Windows 8.1</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Azure Mobile App offline features allow you to interact with a local database when you are in an offline scenario.
trans-unit.target: Azure Mobile App offline features allow you to interact with a local database when you are in an offline scenario.

trans-unit.source: To use these features in your app, you initialize a MobileServiceClient.SyncContext to a local store.
trans-unit.target: To use these features in your app, you initialize a MobileServiceClient.SyncContext to a local store.

trans-unit.source: Then reference your table through the IMobileServiceSyncTable interface.
trans-unit.target: Then reference your table through the IMobileServiceSyncTable interface.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial we use SQLite for the local store.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial we use SQLite for the local store.

trans-unit.source: Install the SQLite runtime for Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1.
trans-unit.target: Install the SQLite runtime for Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1.

trans-unit.source: Windows 8.1 Runtime: Install [SQLite for Windows 8.1].
trans-unit.target: Windows 8.1 Runtime: Install [SQLite for Windows 8.1].

trans-unit.source: Windows Phone 8.1: Install [SQLite for Windows Phone 8.1].
trans-unit.target: Windows Phone 8.1: Install [SQLite for Windows Phone 8.1].

trans-unit.source: If you are using Internet Explorer, clicking the link to install SQLite may prompt you to download the .vsix as a .zip file.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Internet Explorer, clicking the link to install SQLite may prompt you to download the .vsix as a .zip file.

trans-unit.source: Save the file to a location on your hard drive with the .vsix extension instead of .zip.
trans-unit.target: Save the file to a location on your hard drive with the .vsix extension instead of .zip.

trans-unit.source: The double click the .vsix file in Windows Explorer to run the installation.
trans-unit.target: The double click the .vsix file in Windows Explorer to run the installation.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio open the project that you completed in the [Create a Windows app] tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio open the project that you completed in the [Create a Windows app] tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore NuGet package for the Windows 8.1 runtime and Windows Phone 8.1 projects.
trans-unit.target: Install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore NuGet package for the Windows 8.1 runtime and Windows Phone 8.1 projects.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right click the solution and click Manage Nuget Packages for Solution to run NuGet Package Manager.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right click the solution and click Manage Nuget Packages for Solution to run NuGet Package Manager.

trans-unit.source: In the "Online" tab, select the option "Include Prerelease" in the dropdown at the top.
trans-unit.target: In the "Online" tab, select the option "Include Prerelease" in the dropdown at the top.

trans-unit.source: Search for SQLiteStore to install the 2.0.0-beta of WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore.
trans-unit.target: Search for SQLiteStore to install the 2.0.0-beta of WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore.

trans-unit.source: Then, add the NuGet reference to both the Windows Store 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 projects.
trans-unit.target: Then, add the NuGet reference to both the Windows Store 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 projects.

trans-unit.source: If the installation creates an additional reference to a different version of SQLite than you have installed, you will get a compilation error.
trans-unit.target: If the installation creates an additional reference to a different version of SQLite than you have installed, you will get a compilation error.

trans-unit.source: You should resolve this error by removing the duplicate in the References node in your projects.
trans-unit.target: You should resolve this error by removing the duplicate in the References node in your projects.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right click References for the Windows 8.1 Runtime and Windows Phone 8.1 platform projects and ensure there is a reference to SQLite, which is located in the Extensions section.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right click References for the Windows 8.1 Runtime and Windows Phone 8.1 platform projects and ensure there is a reference to SQLite, which is located in the Extensions section.

trans-unit.source: <linkText></linkText> </br>
trans-unit.target: <linkText></linkText> </br>

trans-unit.source: Windows 8.1 Runtime
trans-unit.target: Windows 8.1 Runtime

trans-unit.source: <linkText></linkText> </br>
trans-unit.target: <linkText></linkText> </br>

trans-unit.source: Windows Phone 8.1
trans-unit.target: Windows Phone 8.1

trans-unit.source: SQLite is a native library and requires that you choose a platform-specific architecture such as x86, x64, or ARM.
trans-unit.target: SQLite is a native library and requires that you choose a platform-specific architecture such as x86, x64, or ARM.

trans-unit.source: Any CPU is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Any CPU is not supported.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, click the Solution at the top, then change the processor architecture drop down box to one of the supported settings that you want to test.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, click the Solution at the top, then change the processor architecture drop down box to one of the supported settings that you want to test.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, in the shared project, open the MainPage.cs file.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, in the shared project, open the MainPage.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Uncomment the following using statements at the top of the file:
trans-unit.target: Uncomment the following using statements at the top of the file:

trans-unit.source: In MainPage.cs, comment the line of code that initializes todoTable as an IMobileServiceTable.
trans-unit.target: In MainPage.cs, comment the line of code that initializes todoTable as an IMobileServiceTable.

trans-unit.source: Uncomment the line of code that initializes todoTable as an IMobileServiceSyncTable:
trans-unit.target: Uncomment the line of code that initializes todoTable as an IMobileServiceSyncTable:

trans-unit.source: In MainPage.cs, in the region marked Offline sync, uncomment the methods InitLocalStoreAsync and SyncAsync.
trans-unit.target: In MainPage.cs, in the region marked Offline sync, uncomment the methods InitLocalStoreAsync and SyncAsync.

trans-unit.source: The method InitLocalStoreAsync initializes the client sync context with a SQLite store.
trans-unit.target: The method InitLocalStoreAsync initializes the client sync context with a SQLite store.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, you can select all commented lines and use the Ctrl+K+U keyboard shortcut to uncomment.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, you can select all commented lines and use the Ctrl+K+U keyboard shortcut to uncomment.

trans-unit.source: Notice in SyncAsync a push operation is executed off the MobileServiceClient.SyncContext instead of the IMobileServicesSyncTable.
trans-unit.target: Notice in SyncAsync a push operation is executed off the MobileServiceClient.SyncContext instead of the IMobileServicesSyncTable.

trans-unit.source: This is because the context tracks changes made by the client for all tables.
trans-unit.target: This is because the context tracks changes made by the client for all tables.

trans-unit.source: This is to cover scenarios where there are relationships between tables.
trans-unit.target: This is to cover scenarios where there are relationships between tables.

trans-unit.source: For more information on this behavior, see [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps].
trans-unit.target: For more information on this behavior, see [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps].

trans-unit.source: In the OnNavigatedTo event handler, uncomment the call to InitLocalStoreAsync:
trans-unit.target: In the OnNavigatedTo event handler, uncomment the call to InitLocalStoreAsync:

trans-unit.source: Uncommment the 3 calls to SyncAsync in the methods InsertTodoItem, UpdateCheckedTodoItem, and ButtonRefresh_Click:
trans-unit.target: Uncommment the 3 calls to SyncAsync in the methods InsertTodoItem, UpdateCheckedTodoItem, and ButtonRefresh_Click:

trans-unit.source: Add exception handlers in the SyncAsync method.
trans-unit.target: Add exception handlers in the SyncAsync method.

trans-unit.source: In an offline situation a MobileServicePushFailedException will be thrown with PushResult.Status == CancelledByNetworkError.
trans-unit.target: In an offline situation a MobileServicePushFailedException will be thrown with PushResult.Status == CancelledByNetworkError.

trans-unit.source: In this PullAsync example, we retrieve all records in the remote todoTable, but it is also possible to filter records by passing a query.
trans-unit.target: In this PullAsync example, we retrieve all records in the remote todoTable, but it is also possible to filter records by passing a query.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter to PullAsync is a query ID that is used for incremental sync, which uses the UpdatedAt timestamp to get only records modified since the last sync.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter to PullAsync is a query ID that is used for incremental sync, which uses the UpdatedAt timestamp to get only records modified since the last sync.

trans-unit.source: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your client application.
trans-unit.target: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your client application.

trans-unit.source: To opt-out of incremental sync, pass null as the query ID.
trans-unit.target: To opt-out of incremental sync, pass null as the query ID.

trans-unit.source: This will retrieve all records on each pull operation, which is potentially inefficient.
trans-unit.target: This will retrieve all records on each pull operation, which is potentially inefficient.

trans-unit.source: Note that the MobileServicePushFailedException can occur for both a push and a pull operation.
trans-unit.target: Note that the MobileServicePushFailedException can occur for both a push and a pull operation.

trans-unit.source: It can occur for a pull because the pull operation internally executes a push to make sure all tables along with any relationships are consistent.
trans-unit.target: It can occur for a pull because the pull operation internally executes a push to make sure all tables along with any relationships are consistent.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to rebuild and run the client app.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to rebuild and run the client app.

trans-unit.source: The app will behave the same as it did before the offline sync changes, because it does a sync operation on the insert, update, and refresh operations.
trans-unit.target: The app will behave the same as it did before the offline sync changes, because it does a sync operation on the insert, update, and refresh operations.

trans-unit.source: However, it will populate a local database which can be used in an offline scenario.
trans-unit.target: However, it will populate a local database which can be used in an offline scenario.

trans-unit.source: We will cause and offline scenario in the next section now that the local database is populated.
trans-unit.target: We will cause and offline scenario in the next section now that the local database is populated.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will modify the client app to simulate an offline scenario by breaking your connection to the Azure Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will modify the client app to simulate an offline scenario by breaking your connection to the Azure Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: When you add data items, your exception handler will inform you that the app is operating in offline mode with PushResult.Status == CancelledByNetworkError.
trans-unit.target: When you add data items, your exception handler will inform you that the app is operating in offline mode with PushResult.Status == CancelledByNetworkError.

trans-unit.source: Items added will be held in the local store, but not synced to the mobile app backend until you are online again and execute a successful push to the Azure Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: Items added will be held in the local store, but not synced to the mobile app backend until you are online again and execute a successful push to the Azure Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: Edit App.xaml.cs in the shared project.
trans-unit.target: Edit App.xaml.cs in the shared project.

trans-unit.source: Comment out the initialization of the MobileServiceClient and add the following lines, which use an invalid mobile app URL:
trans-unit.target: Comment out the initialization of the MobileServiceClient and add the following lines, which use an invalid mobile app URL:

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to build and run the app.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to build and run the app.

trans-unit.source: Notice your sync failed on refresh when the app launched.
trans-unit.target: Notice your sync failed on refresh when the app launched.

trans-unit.source: Enter some new todo items and click Save for each one.
trans-unit.target: Enter some new todo items and click Save for each one.

trans-unit.source: Push fails for each one with a PushResult.Status=CancelledByNetworkError.
trans-unit.target: Push fails for each one with a PushResult.Status=CancelledByNetworkError.

trans-unit.source: The new todo items exist only in the local store until they can be pushed to the mobile app backend.
trans-unit.target: The new todo items exist only in the local store until they can be pushed to the mobile app backend.

trans-unit.source: You could suppress the exception dialog for PushResult.Status=CancelledByNetworkError, then client app would behave as if its connected to the mobile app backend supporting all create, read, update, delete (CRUD) operations seamlessly.
trans-unit.target: You could suppress the exception dialog for PushResult.Status=CancelledByNetworkError, then client app would behave as if its connected to the mobile app backend supporting all create, read, update, delete (CRUD) operations seamlessly.

trans-unit.source: Close the app and restart it to verify that the new items you created are persisted to the local store.
trans-unit.target: Close the app and restart it to verify that the new items you created are persisted to the local store.

trans-unit.source: (Optional) Use Visual Studio to view your Azure SQL Database table to see that the data in the backend database has not changed.
trans-unit.target: (Optional) Use Visual Studio to view your Azure SQL Database table to see that the data in the backend database has not changed.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to your database in Azure->SQL Databases.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to your database in Azure->SQL Databases.

trans-unit.source: Right-click your database and select Open in SQL Server Object Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Right-click your database and select Open in SQL Server Object Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Now you can browse to your SQL database table and its contents.
trans-unit.target: Now you can browse to your SQL database table and its contents.

trans-unit.source: (Optional) Use a REST tool such as Fiddler or Postman to query your mobile backend, using a GET query in the form https://your-mobile-app-backend-name.azurewebsites.net/tables/TodoItem.
trans-unit.target: (Optional) Use a REST tool such as Fiddler or Postman to query your mobile backend, using a GET query in the form https://your-mobile-app-backend-name.azurewebsites.net/tables/TodoItem.

trans-unit.source: In this section you reconnect the app to the mobile app backend.
trans-unit.target: In this section you reconnect the app to the mobile app backend.

trans-unit.source: This simulates the app moving from an offline state to an online state with the mobile app backend.
trans-unit.target: This simulates the app moving from an offline state to an online state with the mobile app backend.

trans-unit.source: When you first run the application, the OnNavigatedTo event handler will call InitLocalStoreAsync.
trans-unit.target: When you first run the application, the OnNavigatedTo event handler will call InitLocalStoreAsync.

trans-unit.source: This will in turn call SyncAsync to sync your local store with the backend database.
trans-unit.target: This will in turn call SyncAsync to sync your local store with the backend database.

trans-unit.source: So the app will attempt to sync on start up.
trans-unit.target: So the app will attempt to sync on start up.

trans-unit.source: Open App.xaml.cs in the shared project.
trans-unit.target: Open App.xaml.cs in the shared project.

trans-unit.source: Uncomment your previous initialization of MobileServiceClient to use the correct Mobile App URL and gateway URL.
trans-unit.target: Uncomment your previous initialization of MobileServiceClient to use the correct Mobile App URL and gateway URL.

trans-unit.source: Press the F5 key to rebuild and run the app.
trans-unit.target: Press the F5 key to rebuild and run the app.

trans-unit.source: The app syncs your local changes with the Azure Mobile App backend using push and pull operations as soon as the OnNavigatedTo event handler executes.
trans-unit.target: The app syncs your local changes with the Azure Mobile App backend using push and pull operations as soon as the OnNavigatedTo event handler executes.

trans-unit.source: (Optional) View the updated data using either SQL Server Object Explorer or a REST tool like Fiddler.
trans-unit.target: (Optional) View the updated data using either SQL Server Object Explorer or a REST tool like Fiddler.

trans-unit.source: Notice the data has been synchronized between the Azure Mobile App backend database and the local store.
trans-unit.target: Notice the data has been synchronized between the Azure Mobile App backend database and the local store.

trans-unit.source: In the app, click the check box beside a few items to complete them in the local store.
trans-unit.target: In the app, click the check box beside a few items to complete them in the local store.

trans-unit.source: UpdateCheckedTodoItem calls SyncAsync to sync the complete each item with the Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: UpdateCheckedTodoItem calls SyncAsync to sync the complete each item with the Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: SyncAsync calls both push and pull.
trans-unit.target: SyncAsync calls both push and pull.

trans-unit.source: However, you should note that whenever you execute a pull against a table that the client has made changes to, a push on the client sync context will always be executed first automatically.
trans-unit.target: However, you should note that whenever you execute a pull against a table that the client has made changes to, a push on the client sync context will always be executed first automatically.

trans-unit.source: This is to ensure all tables in the local store, along with relationships remain consistent.
trans-unit.target: This is to ensure all tables in the local store, along with relationships remain consistent.

trans-unit.source: So in this case we could have removed the call to PushAsync because it is executed automatically when executing a pull.
trans-unit.target: So in this case we could have removed the call to PushAsync because it is executed automatically when executing a pull.

trans-unit.source: This behavior may result in an unexpected push if you are not aware of it.
trans-unit.target: This behavior may result in an unexpected push if you are not aware of it.

trans-unit.source: For more information on this behavior, see [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps].
trans-unit.target: For more information on this behavior, see [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps].

trans-unit.source: In order to support the offline features of mobile services, we used the IMobileServiceSyncTable interface and initialized MobileServiceClient.SyncContext with a local store.
trans-unit.target: In order to support the offline features of mobile services, we used the IMobileServiceSyncTable interface and initialized MobileServiceClient.SyncContext with a local store.

trans-unit.source: In this case the local store was a SQLite database.
trans-unit.target: In this case the local store was a SQLite database.

trans-unit.source: The normal CRUD operations for mobile services work as if the app is still connected but, all the operations occur against the local store.
trans-unit.target: The normal CRUD operations for mobile services work as if the app is still connected but, all the operations occur against the local store.

trans-unit.source: When we want to synchronize the local store with the server, we used the IMobileServiceSyncTable.PullAsync and MobileServiceClient.SyncContext.PushAsync methods.
trans-unit.target: When we want to synchronize the local store with the server, we used the IMobileServiceSyncTable.PullAsync and MobileServiceClient.SyncContext.PushAsync methods.

trans-unit.source: To push changes to the server, we called IMobileServiceSyncContext.PushAsync().
trans-unit.target: To push changes to the server, we called IMobileServiceSyncContext.PushAsync().

trans-unit.source: This method is a member of IMobileServicesSyncContext instead of the sync table because it will push changes across all tables.
trans-unit.target: This method is a member of IMobileServicesSyncContext instead of the sync table because it will push changes across all tables.

trans-unit.source: Only records that have been modified in some way locally (through CUD operations) will be sent to the server.
trans-unit.target: Only records that have been modified in some way locally (through CUD operations) will be sent to the server.

trans-unit.source: To pull data from a table on the server to the app, we called IMobileServiceSyncTable.PullAsync.
trans-unit.target: To pull data from a table on the server to the app, we called IMobileServiceSyncTable.PullAsync.

trans-unit.source: A pull always issues a sync context push first if the client sync context has tracked changes on that table.
trans-unit.target: A pull always issues a sync context push first if the client sync context has tracked changes on that table.

trans-unit.source: This is to ensure all tables in the local store along with relationships remain consistent.
trans-unit.target: This is to ensure all tables in the local store along with relationships remain consistent.

trans-unit.source: There are also overloads of PullAsync() that allow a query to be specified in order to filter the data that is stored on the client.
trans-unit.target: There are also overloads of PullAsync() that allow a query to be specified in order to filter the data that is stored on the client.

trans-unit.source: If a query is not passed, PullAsync() will pull all rows in the corresponding table (or query).
trans-unit.target: If a query is not passed, PullAsync() will pull all rows in the corresponding table (or query).

trans-unit.source: You can pass the query to filter only the changes your app needs to sync with.
trans-unit.target: You can pass the query to filter only the changes your app needs to sync with.

trans-unit.source: To enable incremental sync, pass a query ID to PullAsync().
trans-unit.target: To enable incremental sync, pass a query ID to PullAsync().

trans-unit.source: The query ID is used to store the last updated timestamp from the results of the last pull operation.
trans-unit.target: The query ID is used to store the last updated timestamp from the results of the last pull operation.

trans-unit.source: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.
trans-unit.target: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.

trans-unit.source: If the query has a parameter, then the same parameter value could be part of the query ID.
trans-unit.target: If the query has a parameter, then the same parameter value could be part of the query ID.

trans-unit.source: For instance, if you are filtering on userid, your unique query ID could be:
trans-unit.target: For instance, if you are filtering on userid, your unique query ID could be:

trans-unit.source: If you want to opt out of incremental sync, pass null as the query ID.
trans-unit.target: If you want to opt out of incremental sync, pass null as the query ID.

trans-unit.source: In this case, all records will be retrieved on every call to PullAsync, which is potentially inefficient.
trans-unit.target: In this case, all records will be retrieved on every call to PullAsync, which is potentially inefficient.

trans-unit.source: Your app should periodically call IMobileServiceSyncTable.PurgeAsync() to purge the local store.
trans-unit.target: Your app should periodically call IMobileServiceSyncTable.PurgeAsync() to purge the local store.

trans-unit.target: [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps]
